messageBody:
>So said Adam Jack on 2003-07-29 --------------------
>J.B Rainsberger wrote:
>

>

Understood, but if it has to be done, then it has to be done....

> >BUT. As I
> >refactor, as code grows, the suites (being separate from the tests) are
>.

>

>maintain test suites. If you need to maintain test suites to do your work,
>then maintaining test suites is, by definition, productive.
>
>We are failing to communicate. Either I am wrong and stubbornly failing to
>see your point (not impossible), or I am not explaining my issues w/ suites

Perhaps a concrete example would be best here, if you are interested in getting to the bottom of things, as it were.

>I agree that suites are a way to group tests and manage test group
>hierarchy, however they aren't (IMHO) a good tool for managing test
>hierarchies.

Agree. They aren't a tool for managing test hierarchies at all -- they *are* the test hierarchies.

JUnit provides a simple, default way to build a test suite from a TestCase subclass. Beyond that, it's your job to build the suite you want. My point is simple -- and I think you keep missing it -- do whatever you need to build a test suite, but don't mistake those custom building process for something that belongs in the framework. Don't confuse TestSuite, which is part of the framework, with creating instances of TestSuite, which is your job. To make it simpler, JUnit provides one way to do it....

<snip />

>I guess I
>figure that if there is an easier way for developers to maintain test
>dependencies, one that improves test results failure analysis, then testing
>will be more effective/efficient. That seems nicely "test infecting" and
>hence junit-like, to me.

Build the suites however you need to.

>Sure, I may be re-inventing the wheel -- and dumbly thinking I have

It's not an addition to suites. It's a way to build suites.

>If you
>just
>can't see it, then so be it. I think the problem with the example I've
>given
>are that they are too small & simple. Perhaps the difference can't be
>explained by simple example.

I invite you to provide a larger example, if you like.

>If the method I am proposing makes sense for a decent chunk of the user
>community, and makes junit more productive for that use case, then I see it
>as a good alternative to test suites (which I feel are becoming obsolete by
>test collectors).

From what I understand, a Test Collector is a way to build a TestSuite. JUnit executes TestSuite objects. It appears that you are talking about a new kind of Test Collector that uses some dependency metadata about tests. That's very cool stuff, but it's not an extension to JUnit: it is a particular use of JUnit.

>No reason why both couldn't be available.

Indeed.

>I believe I am saying/seeing a different between a human maintaining
>disjointed groupings (suites) and a human maintaining simple assertions of
>dependency of a testcase on other testcases (or suites, I guess), and the
>engine (runner) calculating the dependency order. I guess I am describing a
>declarative mechanism (like ant) verses .. what would one call it ...
>procedural?

Then it *is* what I think it is. You're just talking about a TestSuite factory that uses markup to create TestSuite objects. Again, it does not belong in the JUnit framework, but rather as an add-on tool.

> >What suite would I create?
>
> I would create the suite I know I need. But then, I don't view

>tests by the objects they test: I view them by the features they support.
>
>

I don't know that it can be: dependency is or is not.

>

>Either a computer program determines the mapping, or you determine the

>

Implementation details.

>Gak, why script it? That isn't going to fit into my eclipse, or ant tasks,
>usage w/o some pain. Some things aren't worth doing unless they are
>accepted
>by the core.

Very well, automate it however you please.

> >Is what I am discussing unreasonable? It seems an easy interface for
>users,
> >and something that junit could manage behind the scenes.
>
> I just don't think it's part of JUnit. It's a new Test Runner, perhaps.
>It's a specialized Test Suite Builder. But the framework already supports
>what you want; someone just has to do the work of building it.
>
>
>Why not? Suites serve a purpose, why couldn't declarative. I agree, it
>means
>changes to the runner, but maybe that is warranted in this age of
>ant/eclipse test collectors...

Maybe I misunderstand Test Collectors -- point me to something to learn more, if you don't mind -- but don't they just create TestSuite objects?

Your way to declare a test suite is already supported by JUnit and a little cute refactoring.

Consider the AllTests pattern. I can reduce it to a collection of AllTests or TestCase class names with a little neat refactoring. Then I can use that little engine to store AllTests as text. The next step is to generate that text by doing a directory scan. Now I have a TestSuite builder that build tests from a part of the file system.

I did nothing to change JUnit. I just decorated it. Does it belong in the framework? I don't think so. That's a question of taste, in my opinion.

So I think we understand each other quite well -- I just don't understand why you think this feature you suggest should be part of the framework? Why isn't it a candidate for JUnit-addons or something like that?

Remember that my goal -- Kent's goal, too -- is to keep JUnit very tight and small. It should provide just enough for everyone, rather than a glut of features that have limited use. The less to learn, the better. If you need more, grab add-on package X, add-on package Y and add-on package Z.

Also, the more magic in the package, the less the users need to learn to use it. I want them to know what they're doing.

Take care.
